Metadata.Title: Consider Employing the Using Statement to Make Sure That Database Connections Are Closed
Metadata.DirectLink: Consider Employing the Using Statement to Make Sure That Database Connections Are Closed
Metadata.Priority: J.D. Meier, Alex Mackman, Blaine Wastell, Prashant Bansode, Chaitanya Bijwe

Content.Data:
Applies to

  • ADO.NET 2.0

What to Do

If developing in C# you can use the 'using' keyword which will automatically dispose resources after their usage.

Why

At compile time, the using statement automatically generates a try and finally block that calls Dispose on the object allocated inside the using block. For connection objects, this ensures that the connection's Close method is called.

When

The using statement is available to developers who use the Microsoft Visual C#® 1.1 and 2.0 and to developers who use Microsoft Visual Basic® .NET 2.0. So when developing in this languages user can use using keyword

How

The following code illustrates this syntax.

using ( SqlConnection conn = new SqlConnection( _connString) )
{
  // Open the connection and access the database
  ...
} // Dispose is called and the connection closed

During compilation, the preceding code is converted into the following equivalent code.

SqlConnection conn = new SqlConnection( _connString);
try
{
  // Open the connection and access the database
  ...
}
finally
{
  conn.Dispose(); // Closes the connection
}

Adapted from Microsoft patterns & practices guidance.
